				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://mastodon.social/share?text=Wireshark%20Tutorial:%20%20Examining%20Qakbot%20Infections%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Ftutorial-qakbot-infection%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Mastodon" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tutorial-qakbot-infection:share:mastodon"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-mastodon-share.svg" alt="Mastodon Icon"></a>
				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/tutorial-qakbot-infection/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2>Overview</h2>
<p><a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/wdsi/threats/malware-encyclopedia-description?Name=Win32%2FQakbot">Qakbot</a> is an information stealer also known as Qbot. This family of malware has been active for years, and Qakbot generates distinct traffic patterns. This <a href="https://www.wireshark.org">Wireshark</a> tutorial reviews a recent packet capture (pcap) from a Qakbot infection. Understanding these traffic patterns can be critical for security professionals when detecting and investigating Qakbot infections.</p>
<p>Note: This tutorial assumes you have a basic knowledge of network traffic and Wireshark. We use a customized column display shown in <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-customizing-wireshark-changing-column-display/">this tutorial</a>. You should also have experience with Wireshark display filters as described in <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-display-filter-expressions/">this additional tutorial</a>.</p>
<p>Please also note that the pcap used for this tutorial contains malware. You should review this pcap in a non-Windows environment. If you are limited to a Windows computer, we suggest reviewing the pcap within a virtual machine (VM) running any of the popular recent Linux distros.</p>
<p>This tutorial will cover the following:</p>
<ul>
<li style="list-style-type: none;">
<ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
<li>Qakbot distribution methods</li>
<li>Initial zip archive from link in an malspam</li>
<li>Windows executable for Qakbot</li>
<li>Post-infection HTTPS activity</li>
<li>Other post-infection traffic</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>The pcap used for this tutorial is located <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/2020/01/29/index.html">here</a>. Download the zip archive named <strong><em>2020-01-29-Qbot-infection-traffic.pcap.zip</em></strong> and extract the pcap. Figure 1 shows our pcap open in Wireshark, ready to review.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104370" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104370" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104370 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/PB-210-image-01-1024x641.jpg" alt="Qakbot Infection Traffic" width="1024" height="641" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/PB-210-image-01-1024x641.jpg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/PB-210-image-01-300x188.jpg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/PB-210-image-01-768x480.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/PB-210-image-01-1536x961.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/PB-210-image-01-900x563.jpg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/PB-210-image-01-370x231.jpg 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/PB-210-image-01.jpg 1600w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104370" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. The pcap for this tutorial.</figcaption></figure>
<h2>Qakbot Distribution Methods</h2>
<p>Qakbot is most often distributed through malicious spam (malspam), but it also has been distributed through exploit kits <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net/2019/11/25/index3.html">as recently as November 2019</a>. In some cases, Qakbot is a follow-up infection caused by different malware like <a href="https://www.us-cert.gov/ncas/alerts/TA18-201A">Emotet</a> as reported in <a href="https://isc.sans.edu/forums/diary/Malspam+pushes+Emotet+with+Qakbot+as+the+followup+malware/24738/">this example from March 2019</a>.</p>
<p>Recent malspam-based distribution campaigns for Qakbot follow a chain of events shown in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104316" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104316" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104316 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-29-1024x618.jpeg" alt="" width="1024" height="618" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-29-1024x618.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-29-300x181.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-29-768x464.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-29-1536x927.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-29-2048x1236.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-29-900x543.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-29-370x223.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104316" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Flow chart from recent Qakbot distribution campaigns.</figcaption></figure>
<h3>Initial Zip Archive from Link in Malspam</h3>
<p>Recent malspam distributing Qakbot uses fake email chains that spoof legitimate email addresses. One such example is shown in Figure 3.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104318" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104318" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104318 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-30-1024x821.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="821" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-30-1024x821.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-30-300x240.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-30-768x616.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-30-1536x1231.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-30-2048x1641.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-30-900x721.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-30-370x297.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104318" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Recent malspam example pushing Qakbot.</figcaption></figure>
<p>URLs from these emails end with a short series of numbers followed by <strong><em>.zip</em></strong>. See Table 1 for a few examples of URLs from Qakbot malspam recently reported on <a href="https://urlhaus.abuse.ch/browse/">URLhaus</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/search?q=Qakbot%20zip&amp;f=live">Twitter</a>.</p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;"><strong>First reported</strong></td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;"><strong>URL for initial zip archive</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2019-12-27</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxps://prajoon.000webhostapp[.]com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/last/033/033.zip</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2019-12-27</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxps://psi-uae[.]com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/last/870853.zip</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2019-12-27</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxps://re365[.]com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/last/85944289/85944289.zip</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2019-12-27</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxps://liputanforex.web[.]id/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/last/794/794.zip</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2020-01-06</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxp://eps.icothanglong.edu[.]vn/forward/13078.zip</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2020-01-22</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxp://hitechrobo[.]com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/ahead/84296848/84296848.zip</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2020-01-22</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxp://faithoasis.000webhostapp.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/ahead/550889.zip</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2020-01-27</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxps://madisonclubbar[.]com/fast/invoice049740.zip</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2020-01-29</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxp://zhinengbao[.]wang/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/lane/00571.zip</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2020-01-29</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxp://bhatner[.]com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/ahead/9312.zip</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 111.333px;">2020-02-03</td>
<td style="width: 612.667px;">hxxp://santedeplus[.]info/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/ending/1582820/1582820.zip</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 1. URLs for the initial zip archive to kick off a Qakbot infection chain.</em></span></p>
<p>In our pcap, you can find the HTTP request for a zip archive using <strong><em>http.request.uri contains .zip</em></strong> in the Wireshark filter as shown in Figure 4.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104320" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104320" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104320 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-31-1024x263.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="263" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-31-1024x263.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-31-300x77.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-31-768x197.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-31-1536x394.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-31-2048x526.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-31-900x231.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-31-370x95.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104320" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Finding the URL for the initial zip archive.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Follow the TCP stream to confirm this is a zip archive as shown in Figure 5 and Figure 6, then try to export the zip archive from the pcap as shown in Figure 7.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104322" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104322" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104322 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-32-1024x657.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="657" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-32-1024x657.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-32-300x192.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-32-768x492.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-32-1536x985.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-32-900x577.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-32-370x237.jpeg 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-32.jpeg 1962w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104322" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Following the TCP stream for the HTTP request from our filter results.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_104324" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104324" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104324 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-33-1024x750.jpeg" alt="" width="1024" height="750" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-33-1024x750.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-33-300x220.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-33-768x562.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-33-1536x1125.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-33-2048x1499.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-33-900x659.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-33-370x271.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104324" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Indicators this URL returned a zip archive.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_104326" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104326" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104326 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-34-1024x663.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="663" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-34-1024x663.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-34-300x194.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-34-768x497.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-34-1536x995.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-34-900x583.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-34-370x240.jpeg 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-34.jpeg 1776w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104326" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Exporting objects from HTTP traffic in the pcap.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In most cases, the menu for <strong><em>File → Export Objects → HTTP</em></strong> should export a zip archive sent over HTTP. Unfortunately, as shown in Figure 8, we cannot export this file named <strong><em>9312.zip</em></strong> because it is separated into hundreds of smaller parts within the export HTTP objects list.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104328" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104328" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104328 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-35-1024x757.jpeg" alt="" width="1024" height="757" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-35-1024x757.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-35-300x222.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-35-768x568.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-35-1536x1135.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-35-900x665.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-35-370x273.jpeg 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-35.jpeg 1572w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104328" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. 9312.zip is broken up into hundreds of objects within the list, so we cannot export it this way.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Fortunately, we can export data from a TCP stream window and edit the binary in a hex editor to remove any hxxP response headers. Use the following steps to extract the zip archive from this pcap:</p>
<ol>
<li style="list-style-type: none;">
<ol>
<li>Follow TCP stream for the HTTP request for 9312.zip.</li>
<li>Show only the response traffic in the TCP stream Window.</li>
<li>Change “Show and save data as” from ASCII to Raw.</li>
<li>Save the data as a binary (I chose to save it as: 9312.zip.bin)</li>
<li>Open the binary in a hex editor and remove the HTTP request headers before the first two bytes of the zip archive (which show as PK in ASCII).</li>
<li>Save the file as a zip archive (I chose to save it as 9312.zip)</li>
<li>Check the file to make sure it’s a zip archive.</li>
</ol>
</li>
</ol>
<p>See Figures 9 through 14 for a visual guide of this process.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104330" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104330" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104330 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-36-1024x675.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="675" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-36-1024x675.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-36-300x198.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-36-768x506.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-36-1536x1012.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-36-2048x1350.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-36-900x593.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-36-370x244.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104330" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Step 2 - When viewing the TCP stream, switch from viewing the entire conversation to viewing only data returned from the server.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_104332" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104332" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104332 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-37-1024x771.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="771" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-37-1024x771.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-37-300x226.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-37-768x578.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-37-1536x1157.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-37-2048x1542.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-37-900x678.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-37-370x279.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104332" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Step 3 - Show and save data as Raw instead of ASCII.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_104334" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104334" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104334 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-38-1024x645.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="645" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-38-1024x645.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-38-300x189.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-38-768x483.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-38-1536x967.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-38-2048x1289.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-38-900x567.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-38-370x233.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104334" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Step 4 - Save this raw data from the TCP stream as a binary.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_104336" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104336" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104336 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-39-1024x609.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="609" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-39-1024x609.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-39-300x178.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-39-768x457.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-39-1536x914.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-39-2048x1219.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-39-900x535.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-39-370x220.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104336" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Step 5 - Open your saved binary in a hex editor and remove any HTTP response data before the first two bytes of the zip archive (that show as PK in ASCII).</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_104338" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104338" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104338 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-40-1024x616.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="616" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-40-1024x616.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-40-300x180.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-40-768x462.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-40-1536x924.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-40-2048x1231.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-40-900x541.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-40-370x222.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104338" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Step 6 - Save your edited binary as a zip archive.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_104340" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104340" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104340 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-41-1024x476.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="476" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-41-1024x476.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-41-300x139.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-41-768x357.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-41-1536x713.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-41-900x418.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-41-370x172.jpeg 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-41.jpeg 1860w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104340" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Step 7 - Confirm the edited file is a zip archive, then extract the VBS file and check the file hashes.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 14 shows how to use a terminal window from a Debian-based Linux distro to check the files. From our pcap, the zip archive should be the same as <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/5121c89e898eadeff9eeef660d92f3cff75700c7f017b33c913a951018a3df9a">this file submitted to VirusTotal</a>. Our extracted VBS file should be the same as <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/51758a9ddf92d19be7c69a60125fb3dfc303152e9bbc77478dfff497422f3d25">this file also submitted to VirusTotal</a>.</p>
<p>A public sandbox analysis of <a href="https://app.any.run/tasks/e2c36659-1070-4665-991c-245e900245b7">our extracted VBS file</a> indicates it generates the next Qakbot-related URL in our infection chain: a URL that returned a Windows executable for Qakbot.</p>
<h2>Windows Executable for Qakbot</h2>
<p>These extracted VBS files generate URLs that return Windows executables for Qakbot. Since December 2019, URLs for Qakbot executables have ended with <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">44444.png</span> or <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">444444.png</span>. See Table 2 for some recent examples of these Qakbot URLs we found using our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/autofocus">AutoFocus</a> Threat Intelligence service.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><strong>First Seen</strong></td>
<td><strong>URL for Qakbot executable</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2019-12-27</td>
<td>hxxp://centre-de-conduite-roannais[.]com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/last/444444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-01-06</td>
<td>hxxp://newsinside[.]info/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/forward/44444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-01-15</td>
<td>hxxp://iike.xolva[.]com/wp-content/themes/keenshot/fast/444444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-01-17</td>
<td>hxxp://deccolab[.]com/fast/444444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-01-21</td>
<td>hxxp://myrestaurant.coupoly[.]com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/along/444444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-01-22</td>
<td>hxxp://alphaenergyeng[.]com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/ahead/444444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-01-23</td>
<td>hxxp://claramohammedschoolstl[.]org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/upwards/444444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-01-23</td>
<td>hxxp://creationzerodechet[.]com/choice/444444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-01-26</td>
<td>hxxp://productsphotostudio[.]com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/lane/444444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-01-27</td>
<td>hxxp://sophistproduction[.]com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/choice/444444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-01-30</td>
<td>hxxp://uofnpress[.]ch/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/side/444444.png</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2020-02-03</td>
<td>hxxp://csrkanjiza[.]rs/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/ending/444444.png</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Table 2. URLs for Qakbot executables.</span></em></p>
<p>In our pcap, find the HTTP GET request for our Qakbot executable using <strong><em>hxxp.request.uri contains .png</em></strong> in the Wireshark filter as shown in Figure 15.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104342" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104342" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104342 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-42-1024x258.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="258" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-42-1024x258.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-42-300x75.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-42-768x193.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-42-1536x386.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-42-2048x515.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-42-900x226.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-42-370x93.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104342" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 15. Finding the URL for our Qakbot executable.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Export this object from the pcap using the <strong><em>File → Export Objects → HTTP</em></strong> menu path as shown in Figure 16 and check the results as shown in Figure 17.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104344" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104344" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104344 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-43-1024x506.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="506" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-43-1024x506.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-43-300x148.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-43-768x379.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-43-1536x759.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-43-2048x1012.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-43-900x445.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-43-370x183.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104344" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 16. Exporting our Qakbot executable from the pcap.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_104346" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104346" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104346 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-44-1024x276.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="276" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-44-1024x276.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-44-300x81.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-44-768x207.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-44-1536x414.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-44-900x243.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-44-370x100.jpeg 370w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-44.jpeg 1846w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104346" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 17. Checking the exported file in a Debian-based Linux terminal window.</figcaption></figure>
<p>From our pcap, the Qakbot executable should be <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/56ee803fa903ab477f939b3894af6771aebf0138abe38ae8e3c41cf96bbb0f2a">this file submitted to VirusTotal</a>. A <a href="https://app.any.run/tasks/fb9cffb1-7797-4827-8446-05fee3d6a3de">public sandbox analysis of this file</a> generated several Qakbot indicators (identified as Qbot).</p>
<h2>Post-infection HTTPS Activity</h2>
<p>Use your basic filter (covered in <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-display-filter-expressions/">this previous WIreshark tutorial</a>) for a quick view of web traffic in our pcap. Scroll down to activity after the HTTP GET request to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">alphaenergyeng[.]com</span> that returned our Qakbot executable. You should see several indicators of HTTPS or SSL/TLS traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">68.1.115[.]106</span> with no associated domain as noted in Figure 18.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104348" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104348" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104348 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-45-1024x608.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="608" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-45-1024x608.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-45-300x178.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-45-768x456.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-45-1536x912.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-45-2048x1216.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-45-900x535.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-45-370x220.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104348" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 18. HTTPS or SSL/TLS traffic caused by Qakbot.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This traffic has unusual certificate issuer data commonly noted during Qakbot infections. We reviewed unusual certificate issuer data in our <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-display-filter-expressions/">previous WIreshark tutorial about Ursnif</a>, so this should be easy to find.</p>
<p>Let’s review our Qakbot certificate issuer data using the following Wireshark filter:</p>
<p><strong><em>Ip.addr eq 68.1.115.186 and ssl.handshake.type eq 11</em></strong></p>
<p>For Wireshark 3.0 or newer, use <strong><em>tls.handshake.type</em></strong> instead of <strong><em>ssl.handshake.type</em></strong>. Select the first frame in your results and expand the frame details window until you find the certificate issuer data as shown in Figure 19.</p>
<figure id="attachment_104350" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104350" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104350 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-46-1024x723.jpeg" alt="Qakbot Infections" width="1024" height="723" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-46-1024x723.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-46-300x212.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-46-768x543.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-46-1536x1085.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-46-2048x1447.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-46-900x636.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-46-370x261.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104350" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 19. Reviewing certificate issuer data from Qakbot traffic.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Patterns for the locality name, organization name, and common name are highly-unusual, not normally found in certificates from legitimate HTTPS, SSL, or TLS traffic. Our example of this issuer data is listed below:</p>
<ul>
<li style="list-style-type: none;">
<ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
<li>id-at-countryName=<strong>ES</strong></li>
<li>id-at-stateOrProvinceName=<strong>IA</strong></li>
<li>id-at-localityName=<strong>Uorh Ofwa</strong></li>
<li>id-at-organizationName=<strong>Coejdut Mavmtko Qxyemk Dxsjie LLC.</strong></li>
<li>id-at-commonName=<strong>gaevietovp.mobi</strong></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h3>Other Post-infection Traffic</h3>
<p>Our pcap contains other activity associated with a Qakbot infection. Each activity is not inherently malicious on its own, but taken together with our previous findings, we can assume a full Qakbot infection.</p>
<p>Another indicator of a Qakbot infection is HTTPS traffic to<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> cdn.speedof[.]me</span>. The domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">speedof[.]me</span> is used by a legitimate Internet speed test service. Although this is not malicious traffic, we frequently see traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cdn.speedof[.]me</span> during Qakbot infections. Figure 20 shows this activity from our pcap.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_104352" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104352" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104352 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-47-1024x622.jpeg" alt="" width="1024" height="622" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-47-1024x622.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-47-300x182.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-47-768x467.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-47-1536x934.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-47-2048x1245.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-47-900x547.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-47-370x225.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104352" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 20. The domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cdn.speedof[.]me</span> within the Qakbot traffic.</figcaption></figure>Qakbot also opens windows from all browsers on an infected Windows host. At approximately 13 minutes and 5 seconds into <a href="https://app.any.run/tasks/fb9cffb1-7797-4827-8446-05fee3d6a3de">this sandbox analysis</a>, the video playback shows Qakbot opening Chrome, then Firefox, then Internet Explorer on a Windows 7 host. This analysis shows Qakbot generated traffic to the following URLs:</p>
<ul>
<li>hxxp://store.nvprivateoffice[.]com/redir_chrome.html</li>
<li>hxxp://store.nvprivateoffice[.]com/redir_ff.html</li>
<li>hxxp://store.nvprivateoffice[.]com/redir_ie.html</li>
</ul>
<p>The domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">nvprivateoffice[.]com</span> has been registered through GoDaddy since 2012, and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">store.nvprivateoffice[.]com</span> shows a default web page for nginx on a Fedora server.</p>
<p>Our pcap for this tutorial is from a Qakbot infection on a Windows 10 host without Chrome or Firefox installed. Our pcap only shows web traffic for Internet Explorer and the new Chromium-based Microsoft Edge. Both times, the URL generated by Qakbot was <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp://store.nvprivateoffice[.]com/redir_ie.html</span>.</p>
<p>To find this traffic, use the following Wireshark filter as shown in Figure 21:</p>
<p><em><span style="font-family: georgia, palatino, serif;"><strong>http.request.full_uri contains store.nvprivateoffice</strong></span></em></p>
<figure id="attachment_104354" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104354" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104354 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-48-1024x315.jpeg" alt="" width="1024" height="315" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-48-1024x315.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-48-300x92.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-48-768x236.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-48-1536x473.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-48-2048x630.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-48-900x277.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-48-370x114.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104354" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 21. Finding Qakbot traffic that opens web browsers on an infected Windows host.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Follow the TCP stream for each of the two HTTP GET requests ending in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">redir_ie.html</span>. The first request has a User-Agent in the HTTP headers for Internet Explorer as shown in Figure 22. The second request for the same URL has a User-Agent in the HTTP headers for the new Chromium-based Microsoft Edge as noted in Figure 23.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_104356" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104356" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104356 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-49-1024x757.jpeg" alt="" width="1024" height="757" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-49-1024x757.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-49-300x222.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-49-768x567.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-49-1536x1135.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-49-2048x1513.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-49-900x665.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-49-370x273.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104356" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 22. Qakbot traffic to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">store.nvprivateoffice[.]com</span> using Internet Explorer 11.</figcaption></figure><figure id="attachment_104358" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104358" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104358 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-50-1024x758.jpeg" alt="" width="1024" height="758" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-50-1024x758.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-50-300x222.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-50-768x568.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-50-1536x1136.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-50-2048x1515.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-50-900x666.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-50-370x274.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104358" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 23. Qakbot traffic to<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> store.nvprivateoffice[.]com</span> using the new Chromium-based Microsoft Edge.</figcaption></figure>Finally, our pcap from the Qakbot-infected host also has email-related TCP traffic to various ports for various email protocols like SMTP, IMAP, and POP3. To get an idea of this non-web-related traffic, use the following Wireshark filter as shown in Figure 25:</p>
<p><strong><em>tcp.flags eq 0x0002 and !(tcp.port eq 80) and !(tcp.port eq 443)</em></strong></p>
<figure id="attachment_104360" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104360" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104360 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-51-1024x864.jpeg" alt="" width="1024" height="864" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-51-1024x864.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-51-300x253.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-51-768x648.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-51-1536x1296.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-51-2048x1728.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-51-900x759.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-51-370x312.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104360" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 25. Getting an idea of the non-web-related traffic from this Qakbot infection.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 25 shows TCP connections and attempted TCP connections to various ports like 25, 110,143, 465, 587, 993, and 995 commonly used by different email protocols. The first two lines in the results show traffic to TCP port 65400, but reviewing the associated TCP streams indicates this also email-related traffic.</p>
<p>Use the following Wireshark filter to get a better idea of email-related traffic from the infected host as shown in Figure 26:</p>
<p><strong><em>smtp or imap or pop</em></strong></p>
<figure id="attachment_104362" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-104362" style="width: 1024px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-104362 size-large lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-52-1024x628.jpeg" alt="" width="1024" height="628" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-52-1024x628.jpeg 1024w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-52-300x184.jpeg 300w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-52-768x471.jpeg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-52-1536x943.jpeg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-52-2048x1257.jpeg 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-52-900x552.jpeg 900w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/word-image-52-370x227.jpeg 370w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-104362" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 26. Finding email-related traffic caused by Qakbot in this pcap.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Follow some of the TCP streams to get a better idea for this type of email traffic. We do not normally see such unencrypted email traffic originating from a Windows client to public IP addresses. Along with other indicators, this <strong><em>smtp or imap or pop</em></strong> filter may reveal Qakbot activity.</p>
<h2>Conclusion</h2>
<p>This tutorial provided tips for examining Windows infections with Qakbot malware. More pcaps with examples of Qakbot activity can be found at <a href="https://www.malware-traffic-analysis.net">malware-traffic-analysis.net</a>.</p>
<p>For more help with Wireshark, see our previous tutorials:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42-customizing-wireshark-changing-column-display/">Customizing Wireshark – Changing Your Column Display</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-display-filter-expressions/">Using Wireshark – Display Filter Expressions</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-identifying-hosts-and-users/">Using Wireshark: Identifying Hosts and Users</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-wireshark-exporting-objects-from-a-pcap/">Using Wireshark: Exporting Objects from a Pcap</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wireshark-tutorial-examining-trickbot-infections/">Wireshark Tutorial: Examining Trickbot Infections</a></li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wireshark-tutorial-examining-ursnif-infections/">Wireshark Tutorial: Examining Ursnif Infections</a></li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 7 June, 2024 at 7:19 AM PDT</span>-->

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tutorial-qakbot-infection:related-resources:Network Abuses Leveraging High-Profile Events: Suspicious Domain Registrations and Other Scams:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-12-06T23:00:40+00:00">December 6, 2024</time></span>

                    <h4 class="post-title">Network Abuses Leveraging High-Profile Events: Suspicious Domain Registrations and Other Scams</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">

                <div class="card-content__link">

                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/12_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Close-up of a person wearing glasses, reflecting computer code on the lens." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/12_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/12_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/12_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/12_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/12_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tutorial-qakbot-infection:related-resources:Lateral Movement on macOS: Unique and Popular Techniques and In-the-Wild Examples:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-11-22T11:00:26+00:00">November 22, 2024</time></span>

                    <h4 class="post-title">Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/mitre/" title="MITRE" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tutorial-qakbot-infection:related-resources:Unraveling Sparkling Pisces’s Tool Set: KLogEXE and FPSpy:MITRE">MITRE</a>

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of SnipBot. Digital abstract background featuring binary code and technology symbols with a blue glow in the shape of a skull." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tutorial-qakbot-infection:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-09-23T21:00:55+00:00">September 23, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/snipbot-romcom-malware-variant/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tutorial-qakbot-infection:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/backdoor/" title="backdoor" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tutorial-qakbot-infection:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:backdoor">Backdoor</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/romcom/" title="RomCom" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tutorial-qakbot-infection:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:RomCom">RomCom</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/snipbot-romcom-malware-variant/" title="Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="tutorial-qakbot-infection:related-resources:Inside SnipBot: The Latest RomCom Malware Variant:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                    </div>
    </div>
    <div class="l-container bs__controls">
      <div class="bs__progress"><span></span></div>
      <div class="bs__navigation"> 
        <ul>
          <li> 
            <button id="prevButton"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/slider-arrow-left.svg" alt="Slider arrow"></button>

  </div>
 
        <div class="be-enlarge-modal" id="enlargedModal">
          <div class="be-enlarge-modal__wrapper">

    </section>

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			                 <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:400px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			                  <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:949px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

					<ul class="footer-menu-nav__list"> 
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item nav-title"> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex" target=_blank  role="link" title="AI-Driven Security Operations Platform" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:AI-Driven Security Operations Platform">AI-Driven Security Operations Platform</a>
						</li>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr"   role="link" title="Cortex XDR" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:AI-Driven Security Operations Platform:Cortex XDR">Cortex XDR</a>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsoar"   role="link" title="Cortex XSOAR" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:AI-Driven Security Operations Platform:Cortex XDR:Cortex XSOAR">Cortex XSOAR</a>
						</li>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xpanse"   role="link" title="Cortex Xpanse" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:AI-Driven Security Operations Platform:Cortex XDR:Cortex XSOAR:Cortex Xpanse">Cortex Xpanse</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item "> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsiam"   role="link" title="Cortex XSIAM" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:AI-Driven Security Operations Platform:Cortex XDR:Cortex XSOAR:Cortex Xpanse:Cortex XSIAM">Cortex XSIAM</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item "> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xpanse/attack-surface-management"   role="link" title="External Attack Surface Protection" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:AI-Driven Security Operations Platform:Cortex XDR:Cortex XSOAR:Cortex Xpanse:Cortex XSIAM:External Attack Surface Protection">External Attack Surface Protection</a>
						</li>

						</li>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/detection-and-response"   role="link" title="Threat Prevention, Detection &amp; Response" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:AI-Driven Security Operations Platform:Cortex XDR:Cortex XSOAR:Cortex Xpanse:Cortex XSIAM:External Attack Surface Protection:Security Automation:Threat Prevention, Detection &amp; Response">Threat Prevention, Detection &amp; Response</a>
						</li>    
					        
					</ul>
				</nav>
						            </div>
            <div class="nav-column">

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.2' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</body>
</html>
